Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: READ! Toolkit, A Knowledge-Based Expert System to Develop Beginning Literacy Curricula in Endangered or Underserved Languages
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop and test a computer-based expert system that will guide development of beginning literacy curricula in any phonics-based language. The system will produce beginning literacy curricula mobile apps for phones and tablets and will include beginning reading, writing, vocabulary-building, and assessment activities. The expert system will (a) minimize cost, time and expertise required to develop early literacy curricula, (b) produce curricula that could increase early reading fluency and bilingualism, which is related to children's improved ability to manage their thoughts, behaviors and emotions, (c) provide effective curricula to learn languages other than English at home or school, (d) revitalize endangered or underserved languages while increasing connections to culture and heritage, which will improve long-term academic, health and economic outcomes for indigenous children or children who speak a language other than English at home, and increase their participation in STEM careers, and (e) contribute to research on bilingualism's impacts on academic, social, emotional, and cultural outcomes. The system will be licensed by underserved language communities, tribes, individuals, and organizations interested in improving literacy, with revenue produced by the mobile app products developed using the expert system shared between curriculum developers and the expert system developer.


This SBIR Phase I project will develop and test a knowledge-based expert system that integrates early literacy research; language analysis to provide evidence-based recommendations for developing decodable text for phonics-based early literacy curricula; evidence-based teaching and formative assessment strategies; curriculum development knowledge; user interface/user experience best-practices; natural language processing for pronunciation feedback; and database and technology skills to guide users who may not have the knowledge and skills in developing a beginning literacy curricula in any language. The best practices and methods based on the research will be incorporated by analyzing text to create lists of sounds/letters and words, their frequencies, and sounds and words that come before and after each sound/word. From these lists, the system will generate language-specific recommendations based on the rules for optimal sequencing of sounds and words for learning to decode in another language. While some evidence-based guidelines needed for decoding in English, which is less phonetically regular than many underserved languages, may not apply in a language that is more phonetically regular, most are expected to. These rules will guide recommendations from which users of the knowledge-based expert system can select sequences sounds, words, and phrases to write decodable, connected text, culturally relevant stories for beginning literacy curricula.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase I project developed and tested a Software as a Service (SaaS) system that incorporates the best practices from the reading research to guide development of beginning literacy curricula in any phonics-based language. The system guides development of sequences of stories—in any alphabetic language—in which the introduction of sounds and words is controlled using evidence-based practices for teaching reading. These sequences of culturally-bound stories form the basis for a beginning literacy curricula, and the software generates practice activities to build reading fluency, as well as writing and vocabulary skills. The system also generates assessments to measure a learner’s progress.

Innovations tested during this Phase 1 project include the following:

(a) Development of software to create a language database in any alphabetic language, with a focus on endangered and/or underserved languages. The language database includes the frequencies of sounds, words, and phrases in the language. English and Spanish language databases are included in the software, and language databased for endangered or underserved langauges can be generated using text-based samples of the language. 

(b) Development of a knowledge-based expert system that encapsulates the best practices from the reading research to guide story development using controlled introduction of sounds and words. In particular, the sytem ensures that evidence-based practices for introducing sounds and words and providing sufficient practice to build reading fluency using a phonics-based approach for teaching reading are encapsulated during story development. 

(c) Development of a software system that keeps track of the sounds and words used in stories to ensure sufficient practice is provided to develop beginning literacy skills, checks to make sure stories include only sounds and words that have been previously taught, and generates practice activities for reading, writing, and vocabulary building.

(d) Outputs from the SaaS include print materials and mobile applications that can be used to teach beginning literacy skills in any alphabetic language, with a focus on endangered and/or underserved languages.

The Literacy Loom SaaS will (a) minimize cost, time and expertise required to develop early literacy curricula, (b) produce curricula that could increase early reading fluency and bilingualism, which is related to children's improved ability to manage their thoughts, behaviors and emotions, (c) provide effective curricula to learn languages other than English at home or school, and (d) revitalize endangered or underserved languages through early literacy while increasing connections to culture and heritage, which should increase learner engagement and academic success for children with Native American heritage or children who speak a language other than English at home. Increased engagement with beginning reading and improved reading fluency could increase children’s later participation in STEM careers.

The SaaS system will be licensed by underserved language communities, including tribes, individuals, and organizations interested in improving literacy, revitalizing languages, and/or ensuring children have the opportunity to learn with culturally-bound stories. Ongoing revenue will be produced by the mobile app products generated using the Literacy Loom system.

The Literacy Loom SaaS integrates early literacy research; language analysis to provide evidence-based recommendations for developing decodable text for phonics-based early literacy curricula; evidence-based teaching and formative assessment strategies; curriculum development knowledge; user interface/user experience best-practices; and database and technology skills. The software guides users who may not have all the knowledge and skills necessary to develop a culturally-bound beginning literacy curriculum in any alphabetic language. The Literacy Loom software was tested using English, Spanish, Ancient Greek, Navajo Diné and Siletz Dee-Ni languages.
